newsitem.title: JAPAN: Sanyo, Yamatane say capital ratios at about 160%.
newsitem.headline: Sanyo, Yamatane say capital ratios at about 160%.

text.p: Sanyo Securities Co Ltd and Yamatane Securities Co Ltd said on Wednesday that their capital-to-risk ratios would be about 160 percent at the end of March.
Dai-Ichi Securities Co Ltd said its capital-to-risk ratio at the end of March would be around 200 percent.
The capital safety ratio is that of net capital and latent profits on securities holdings against risk assets and possible losses from the securities business.
The ratio is regarded as an index gauging the health of a brokerage's operations. Analysts said a capital-to-risk ratio of 200 percent or lower was considered to be dangerous.
The three securities houses did not elaborate further.
Under guidelines set by the Ministry of Finance, brokerages must maintain capital-to-risk ratios above 120 percent.
If they fail to do so, the ministry can call on them to raise the ratios by any means or to halt business for three months.
